title: Trump, Scrutinized Over Interaction With Ukraine, Still Calls for Biden Probe
text:
President Trump pressed on with calls for an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden, his potential Democratic opponent, after The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. Trump repeatedly pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to undertake such a probe.

The Trump campaign sent supporters an email on Saturday echoing the calls by the president and his lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, to investigate Mr. Biden over widely discredited allegations of impropriety. “What is Joe Biden hiding?” the email read. Mr. Trump in tweets accused Democrats and the media of starting a “Ukraine Witch Hunt.”

Mr. Biden, speaking to reporters while campaigning in Des Moines, Iowa, angrily pushed back against the president’s assertions, denouncing Mr. Trump as “a serial abuser” whose interactions with Ukraine represented an “overwhelming abuse of power.”

The exchange followed a Journal report on Friday that said Mr. Trump in a July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged him about eight times to work with Mr. Giuliani on an investigation into Mr. Biden, according to people familiar with the matter.

Mr. Trump on Saturday said the call was “perfectly fine and routine” but didn’t address whether he had pressured Mr. Zelensky to investigate the Democratic front-runner.

Mr. Giuliani has suggested that Mr. Biden as vice president worked to shield from investigation a Ukrainian gas company whose board counted Mr. Biden’s son, Hunter, as a member.

Former Vice President Joe Biden greeted guests at the Polk County Democrats' Steak Fry in Des Moines, Iowa, on Saturday. Photo: Scott Olson/Getty Images

Mr. Biden, as vice president, did call for the ouster of former Ukrainian prosecutor general, Viktor Shokin, but his call was part of a broader effort by Ukrainian anticorruption investigators, European diplomats, U.S. allies and the U.S. State Department to overhaul a prosecutor’s office that was widely viewed as corrupt.

Mr. Shokin, as Ukraine’s prosecutor general, faced criticism from Ukrainian investigators and some Western officials for what they said wasn’t doing enough to investigate Burisma Group, a company on whose board Hunter Biden sat, for alleged wrongdoing. The probe into the company was no longer active when Mr. Shokin was removed from office in 2016.

Yuriy Lutsenko, Ukraine’s prosecutor general at the time, said earlier this year he had no evidence of wrongdoing by Mr. Biden or his son.

Mr. Biden told reporters in Des Moines on Saturday that he had never discussed with his son any overseas business dealings and called for Mr. Trump to be investigated.

“He is violating every basic norm of a president,” Mr. Biden said. “He’s using the abuse of power and every element of the presidency to try to do something to smear me.”

The scrutiny of Mr. Trump’s dealings with his Ukrainian counterpart is likely to escalate in the coming weeks as Congress continues to probe a whistleblower complaint said to be about the president’s dealings with at least one foreign leader. Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire is scheduled to appear next week before both the Senate and House intelligence committees, where he will be asked about his decision not to share the complaint with lawmakers.

On Saturday, Mark Zaid, a prominent national security lawyer who has represented whistleblowers for over 20 years, said on Twitter he had joined the legal team of the still-unidentified whistleblower. The complainant is represented by Andrew Bakaj, a former intelligence and Pentagon official who runs his own practice focused on whistleblower matters.

—Dustin Volz contributed to this article.

Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com and John McCormick at mccormick.john@wsj.com
description: President Trump pressed on with calls for an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden after The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. Trump repeatedly pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to undertake such a probe.
